subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] order of letters for learning
msgSnippet: Dear Jack When I started out, like you I worked through the manual but then I just went into writing and reading, looking up any glyph I didn t know.  I soon
messageBody:
Dear Jack

When I started out, like you I worked through the manual but then I just went into writing and reading, looking up any glyph I didn't know.  I soon found that I could remember the common letters.

The ones that I found confusing and difficult to get right were Pip and HaHa (using the modern names for the letters), Awl and Ah and Out and Oil - I confess that I still make mistakes with those.

I created a crib list which I kept in my pocket at all times - in fact I still have crib sheets which I created to remind me of the keyboard mapping for the Jerome font plus the font that I am trying to create now - I still find I refer to these.  On one side is the keyboard mapping and the other has the common abbreviations.

regards

Moira

Moira O'Brien LIPF
Moira O'Brien Photography

Tel +353 (0)766-153852
Tel: +44 (0)845-527 9190

2009/6/14 John Cowan <cowan@...>


Robert å?¸é£? Will scripsit:



> I am currently learning to write and read Quikscript. I followed
> Read's manual and started with the letters .tea and .no, as well as
> .it, .eat, .et, .eight, and .at. These are really great, because they
> form so many words. I even found ones that weren't in the manual, such
> as "teen", "tenant", and "eighty". Then I added the letter .aye to the
> pack and found a lot of words that I could write. But then I got
> stuck: for .ah and .awe, I did not find any words which use only
> letters previously learned, while for .ox I found only "on", and for
> .oy I found only "toy" and "annoy" (at least).

For AWE you have "naught"; not a very common word, but there it is.

--
Cash registers don't really add and subtract; John Cowan
they only grind their gears. cowan@...
But then they don't really grind their gears, either;
they only obey the laws of physics. --Unknown
